subject: Re: [junit] One test class per class (was Testing multiple interfaces?)
msgSnippet: ... Or use subversion, which happily allows you to rename files.  ;-)
messageBody:
On 6/7/05, Chris Dollin <kers@...> wrote:
> On Monday 06 June 2005 19:10, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > Chris Dollin wrote:
> > > On Friday 03 June 2005 18:07, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > > > Yes. Even worse: two possibly overlapping, but often disjoint, sets
> of
> > > > test fixture objects in the same test case class. Some tests use
> > > > fixture A and others use fixture B. Why not put those in separate
> test
> > > > case classes for clarity?
> > >
> > > Because of the activation energy required to split off a new class,
> move
> > > the right methods into it, remember to link it into the next level up,
> > > add it to change control, fix the pesky layout infelicities the IDE
> likes
> > > to avoid providing a configure-out option for, refactor the class
> > > comments, etc?
> > >
> > > [Pairing is good. Would that I could.]
> >
> > It sounds more like quite a viscous environment (either the codebase,
> > the IDE, or a combination of the two): it's easier to do a bad thing
> > than a good thing.
> >
> > Which IDE, you poor soul? In Eclipse it's just "new class, copy, run
> > tests, delete, run tests, update, commit". Well, except for the class
> > comments, I guess. For that you're on your own. :)
>
> Eclipse.
>
> So that's "new class". Copy. Fix layout. Fix suite(). Run tests. Delete
> tests. Run. Delete other tests in other class. Run. Check that the two
> classes are a partition of the original class. (One *must* do this, so
> it's probably better to do moves than deletes.) Look for shared code
> and partition it or move it to a suitable (possibly new) superclass.
> (There's usually some helper code like this.) Link the suite() into
> the parent suite. (Yes, we don't use the automatic recursive suite
> creation. Close call: but sometimes being able to trivially comment
> out subsuites has made bug-tracking much much easier, since we do
> sometimes end up with context-sensitive problems. Perhaps we just
> have too many global caches.) Run complete test suite. Stare hard
> at the new classname, rename to suitable, because now you have to
> introduce it to CVS, and renaming it later is a pain. Perform
> introduction. No, I don't want the file CVSed when it's created, since
> if I want to back it out later (when I realise I made a complete mess)
> I don't want dirty footprints in the repository. OK, everything works.
> Check in. Wait forever for CVS to complete. Time passes. Maybe there's
> some mail to read? Yes. Whoppee, CVS done. Change to paranoia window.
> CVS update. Wait forever for CVS to complete. Time passes. Mail already
> read, read news instead. CVS completes. ant build, run tests, all pass.
> Hooray! Don't do this on a Friday afternoon, you'll likely miss your
> train or break the build.
>
> Somewhere in there I fixed the auto-layout. And did a CVS update (Wait.
> Time passes. Get tea.) before running the tests.
>
> What do you do that if I did it too I could do better? Apart from using
> a faster CVS server, that is.
>

Or use subversion, which happily allows you to rename files. ;-)
